messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
Default to use Python when not specified where applicable.
Always write python tests with the prefix `test_`.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements**:

1. **User Registration and Authentication**:
    - Sign up using email.
    - Forgotten password recovery.

2. **User Profile**:
    - Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
    - Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

3. **Contact Management**:
    - Block/unblock contacts.
    - Create, edit, and manage groups.

4. **Messaging**:
    - Send and receive real-time text messages.
    - Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
    - End-to-end encryption for security.
    - Image sharing.
    - Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

5. **Group Chats**:
    - Create group chats with a name and picture.
    - Add or remove participants.
    - Admin roles and permissions.

6. **Status/Story Feature**:
    - Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
    - Control who can see the status.

7. **Web Application**:
    - Web-based version accessible from browsers.

8. **Connectivity and Offline Mode**:
    - Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
    - Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.

function_call.name: provide_detailed_sub_task_steps_for_sub_agents
function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "1. **Project Setup**: Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new Python project and initialize it with a `requirements.txt` file. This file will list all the Python packages that are required for the project. Some of the packages that will be needed include Flask (for creating the web application), Flask-SocketIO (for real-time communication), Flask-SQLAlchemy (for database operations), Flask-Login (for user authentication), Flask-WTF (for form handling), and Pillow (for image processing). Create a `main.py` file which will serve as the entry point of the application. Also, create a `config.py` file for storing configuration variables such as the secret key and database URI. Write tests to ensure that the project setup is correct and all the required packages are installed.",

    "2. **User Registration and Authentication**: Create a `models.py` file and define a `User` class in it. This class will represent the users of the chat application and will have fields such as `id`, `email`, `password`, `profile_picture`, `status_message`, `last_seen`, and `privacy_settings`. The `User` class should also have methods for setting and checking passwords. Next, create a `forms.py` file and define a `RegistrationForm` and a `LoginForm` in it. These forms will be used for user registration and login respectively. The `RegistrationForm` should have fields for email and password, and the `LoginForm` should have fields for email and password. Write tests to ensure that user registration and authentication are working correctly.",

    "3. **User Profile**: Add methods to the `User` class for setting and getting the profile picture and status message. Also, add a method for updating the privacy settings. Write tests to ensure that these methods are working correctly.",

    "4. **Contact Management**: Define a `Contact` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the contacts of a user and will have fields such as `id`, `user_id`, `contact_id`, and `blocked`. The `user_id` and `contact_id` fields will be foreign keys referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `blocked` field will indicate whether the contact is blocked or not. Add methods to the `User` class for blocking and unblocking contacts. Write tests to ensure that contact management is working correctly.",

    "5. **Messaging**: Define a `Message` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the messages sent between users and will have fields such as `id`, `sender_id`, `receiver_id`, `text`, `timestamp`, `read`, and `encrypted`. The `sender_id` and `receiver_id` fields will be foreign keys referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `read` field will indicate whether the message has been read or not, and the `encrypted` field will indicate whether the message is encrypted or not. Add methods to the `User` class for sending and receiving messages. Write tests to ensure that messaging is working correctly.",

    "6. **Group Chats**: Define a `Group` class and a `GroupMessage` class in the `models.py` file. The `Group` class will represent the group chats and will have fields such as `id`, `name`, `picture`, and `admin_id`. The `admin_id` field will be a foreign key referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `GroupMessage` class will represent the messages sent in a group chat and will have fields similar to the `Message` class. Add methods to the `User` class for creating, joining, and leaving group chats. Write tests to ensure that group chats are working correctly.",

    "7. **Status/Story Feature**: Define a `Status` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the statuses posted by users and will have fields such as `id`, `user_id`, `image`, `timestamp`, and `visibility`. The `user_id` field will be a foreign key referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `visibility` field will indicate who can see the status. Add methods to the `User` class for posting and viewing statuses. Write tests to ensure that the status/story feature is working correctly.",

    "8. **Web Application**: Create a `routes.py` file and define routes for the various pages of the web application such as the home page, login page, registration page, chat page, group chat page, and status page. Each route should render a corresponding HTML template. Create a `templates` folder and add HTML templates for each of the pages. Also, create a `static` folder for storing static files such as CSS stylesheets, JavaScript scripts, and images. Write tests to ensure that the web application is working correctly.",

    "9. **Connectivity and Offline Mode**: Add a `last_seen` field to the `User` class to track when a user was last online. Also, add a `queued_messages` field to the `User` class to store messages that are to be sent when the user is offline. Write tests to ensure that the connectivity and offline mode features are working correctly.",

    "10. **Final Testing and Deployment**: After all the features have been implemented, perform a final round of testing to ensure that everything is working as expected. Fix any bugs that are found and make any necessary improvements. Once everything is working correctly, deploy the application to a web server."
  ]
}

app/forms.py: from wtforms import StringField, PasswordField, SubmitField
from wtforms.validators import DataRequired, Email, EqualTo, ValidationError
raise ValidationError('Please use a different email address.')

steps: 1. **Project Setup**: Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new Python project and initialize it with a `requirements.txt` file. This file will list all the Python packages that are required for the project. Some of the packages that will be needed include Flask (for creating the web application), Flask-SocketIO (for real-time communication), Flask-SQLAlchemy (for database operations), Flask-Login (for user authentication), Flask-WTF (for form handling), and Pillow (for image processing). Create a `main.py` file which will serve as the entry point of the application. Also, create a `config.py` file for storing configuration variables such as the secret key and database URI. Write tests to ensure that the project setup is correct and all the required packages are installed.

2. **User Registration and Authentication**: Create a `models.py` file and define a `User` class in it. This class will represent the users of the chat application and will have fields such as `id`, `email`, `password`, `profile_picture`, `status_message`, `last_seen`, and `privacy_settings`. The `User` class should also have methods for setting and checking passwords. Next, create a `forms.py` file and define a `RegistrationForm` and a `LoginForm` in it. These forms will be used for user registration and login respectively. The `RegistrationForm` should have fields for email and password, and the `LoginForm` should have fields for email and password. Write tests to ensure that user registration and authentication are working correctly.

3. **User Profile**: Add methods to the `User` class for setting and getting the profile picture and status message. Also, add a method for updating the privacy settings. Write tests to ensure that these methods are working correctly.

4. **Contact Management**: Define a `Contact` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the contacts of a user and will have fields such as `id`, `user_id`, `contact_id`, and `blocked`. The `user_id` and `contact_id` fields will be foreign keys referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `blocked` field will indicate whether the contact is blocked or not. Add methods to the `User` class for blocking and unblocking contacts. Write tests to ensure that contact management is working correctly.

5. **Messaging**: Define a `Message` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the messages sent between users and will have fields such as `id`, `sender_id`, `receiver_id`, `text`, `timestamp`, `read`, and `encrypted`. The `sender_id` and `receiver_id` fields will be foreign keys referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `read` field will indicate whether the message has been read or not, and the `encrypted` field will indicate whether the message is encrypted or not. Add methods to the `User` class for sending and receiving messages. Write tests to ensure that messaging is working correctly.

6. **Group Chats**: Define a `Group` class and a `GroupMessage` class in the `models.py` file. The `Group` class will represent the group chats and will have fields such as `id`, `name`, `picture`, and `admin_id`. The `admin_id` field will be a foreign key referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `GroupMessage` class will represent the messages sent in a group chat and will have fields similar to the `Message` class. Add methods to the `User` class for creating, joining, and leaving group chats. Write tests to ensure that group chats are working correctly.

7. **Status/Story Feature**: Define a `Status` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the statuses posted by users and will have fields such as `id`, `user_id`, `image`, `timestamp`, and `visibility`. The `user_id` field will be a foreign key referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `visibility` field will indicate who can see the status. Add methods to the `User` class for posting and viewing statuses. Write tests to ensure that the status/story feature is working correctly.

8. **Web Application**: Create a `routes.py` file and define routes for the various pages of the web application such as the home page, login page, registration page, chat page, group chat page, and status page. Each route should render a corresponding HTML template. Create a `templates` folder and add HTML templates for each of the pages. Also, create a `static` folder for storing static files such as CSS stylesheets, JavaScript scripts, and images. Write tests to ensure that the web application is working correctly.

9. **Connectivity and Offline Mode**: Add a `last_seen` field to the `User` class to track when a user was last online. Also, add a `queued_messages` field to the `User` class to store messages that are to be sent when the user is offline. Write tests to ensure that the connectivity and offline mode features are working correctly.

10. **Final Testing and Deployment**: After all the features have been implemented, perform a final round of testing to ensure that everything is working as expected. Fix any bugs that are found and make any necessary improvements. Once everything is working correctly, deploy the application to a web server.
step: 5. **Messaging**: Define a `Message` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the messages sent between users and will have fields such as `id`, `sender_id`, `receiver_id`, `text`, `timestamp`, `read`, and `encrypted`. The `sender_id` and `receiver_id` fields will be foreign keys referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `read` field will indicate whether the message has been read or not, and the `encrypted` field will indicate whether the message is encrypted or not. Add methods to the `User` class for sending and receiving messages. Write tests to ensure that messaging is working correctly.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

sub_messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements**:

1. **User Registration and Authentication**:
    - Sign up using email.
    - Forgotten password recovery.

2. **User Profile**:
    - Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
    - Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

3. **Contact Management**:
    - Block/unblock contacts.
    - Create, edit, and manage groups.

4. **Messaging**:
    - Send and receive real-time text messages.
    - Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
    - End-to-end encryption for security.
    - Image sharing.
    - Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

5. **Group Chats**:
    - Create group chats with a name and picture.
    - Add or remove participants.
    - Admin roles and permissions.

6. **Status/Story Feature**:
    - Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
    - Control who can see the status.

7. **Web Application**:
    - Web-based version accessible from browsers.

8. **Connectivity and Offline Mode**:
    - Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
    - Display online/offline status.
```

    "1. **Project Setup**: Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new Python project and initialize it with a `requirements.txt` file. This file will list all the Python packages that are required for the project. Some of the packages that will be needed include Flask (for creating the web application), Flask-SocketIO (for real-time communication), Flask-SQLAlchemy (for database operations), Flask-Login (for user authentication), Flask-WTF (for form handling), and Pillow (for image processing). Create a `main.py` file which will serve as the entry point of the application. Also, create a `config.py` file for storing configuration variables such as the secret key and database URI. Write tests to ensure that the project setup is correct and all the required packages are installed.",

    "2. **User Registration and Authentication**: Create a `models.py` file and define a `User` class in it. This class will represent the users of the chat application and will have fields such as `id`, `email`, `password`, `profile_picture`, `status_message`, `last_seen`, and `privacy_settings`. The `User` class should also have methods for setting and checking passwords. Next, create a `forms.py` file and define a `RegistrationForm` and a `LoginForm` in it. These forms will be used for user registration and login respectively. The `RegistrationForm` should have fields for email and password, and the `LoginForm` should have fields for email and password. Write tests to ensure that user registration and authentication are working correctly.",

    "3. **User Profile**: Add methods to the `User` class for setting and getting the profile picture and status message. Also, add a method for updating the privacy settings. Write tests to ensure that these methods are working correctly.",

    "4. **Contact Management**: Define a `Contact` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the contacts of a user and will have fields such as `id`, `user_id`, `contact_id`, and `blocked`. The `user_id` and `contact_id` fields will be foreign keys referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `blocked` field will indicate whether the contact is blocked or not. Add methods to the `User` class for blocking and unblocking contacts. Write tests to ensure that contact management is working correctly.",

    "5. **Messaging**: Define a `Message` class in the `models.py` file. This class will represent the messages sent between users and will have fields such as `id`, `sender_id`, `receiver_id`, `text`, `timestamp`, `read`, and `encrypted`. The `sender_id` and `receiver_id` fields will be foreign keys referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `read` field will indicate whether the message has been read or not, and the `encrypted` field will indicate whether the message is encrypted or not. Add methods to the `User` class for sending and receiving messages. Write tests to ensure that messaging is working correctly.",

    "6. **Group Chats**: Define a `Group` class and a `GroupMessage` class in the `models.py` file. The `Group` class will represent the group chats and will have fields such as `id`, `name`, `picture`, and `admin_id`. The `admin_id` field will be a foreign key referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `GroupMessage` class will represent the messages sent in a group chat and will have fields similar to the `Message` class. Add methods to the `User` class for creating, joining, and leaving group chats. Write tests to ensure that group chats are working correctly.",

    "7. **Status/Story Feature**: Define a `Status` class in the `models.py` file. The `user_id` field will be a foreign key referencing the `id` field of the `User` class. The `visibility` field will indicate who can see the status. Add methods to the `User` class for posting and viewing statuses. Write tests to ensure that the status/story feature is working correctly.",

    "8. **Web Application**: Create a `routes.py` file and define routes for the various pages of the web application such as the home page, login page, registration page, chat page, group chat page, and status page. Also, create a `static` folder for storing static files such as CSS stylesheets, JavaScript scripts, and images. Write tests to ensure that the web application is working correctly.",

    "9. **Connectivity and Offline Mode**: Add a `last_seen` field to the `User` class to track when a user was last online. Write tests to ensure that the connectivity and offline mode features are working correctly.",
